results.title: The Deafening Silence of a Coronavirus Championship
results.abstract: Many sports have returned to play without fans. Golf is deciding a major championship without them. For players used to feeding off the crowd’s energy and reactions, it’s just not the same.

multimedia.caption: Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods and Justin Thomas walking up the 18th fairway, alone, on Friday.
Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods and Justin Thomas walking up the 18th fairway, alone, on Friday.
Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods and Justin Thomas walking up the 18th fairway, alone, on Friday.
Rory McIlroy, Tiger Woods and Justin Thomas walking up the 18th fairway, alone, on Friday.

results.title: Pac-12 Players Say Commissioner Was Dismissive of Their Virus Concerns
results.abstract: The players, who have pushed for more-frequent virus testing and stronger protection of their status with the team, said Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott offered no concrete mandates for the league’s universities.

multimedia.caption: Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott was criticized by football players after a meeting in which they said he was dismissive of their concerns about the coronavirus.
multimedia.copyright: Kirby Lee/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

results.title: America Could Control the Pandemic by October. Let’s Get to It.
results.abstract: The solutions to combating the coronavirus are no mystery. It’s time to do this right.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: Robbie Waters, an Old-School Cop and Legislator, Dies at 84
results.abstract: A Sacramento fixture, Mr. Waters drove a 1932 Ford and crossed paths with Patty Hearst and Squeaky Fromme. He died of the coronavirus.

multimedia.caption: Robbie Waters in around 1982. In his 44-year career of public service, he had a knack for attracting news cameras.

results.title: ‘Godspell’ Review: Musical Theater Rises From the Dead
results.abstract: The Berkshire Theater Group put on the first professional musical in the U.S. since the pandemic lockdown, and it’s a revival in every sense.

multimedia.caption: Nicholas Edwards, center, as Jesus in the Berkshire Theater Group’s socially distanced production of “Godspell.”
Nicholas Edwards, center, as Jesus in the Berkshire Theater Group’s socially distanced production of “Godspell.”

results.title: Richard Lapointe, Exonerated in a Murder Case, Dies at 74
results.abstract: Advocates worked for decades to free him in the murder of his wife’s grandmother in Connecticut; in 2015 a court finally agreed.

multimedia.caption: Richard Lapointe, center, with Kate Germond of Centurion Ministries, which fights wrongful convictions, and the lawyer Paul Casteleiro in Hartford, Conn., after Mr. Lapointe’s 1992 murder conviction was overturned in 2015.
multimedia.copyright: Jared Ramsdell/Journal Inquirer, via Associated Press

results.title: Remains of Sailor and 7 Marines Killed in Training Accident Are Recovered
results.abstract: The servicemen had been missing since the amphibious assault vehicle they were in sank off the coast of Southern California on July 30.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: Protests Erupt on the Streets of a Battered Beirut
results.abstract: Demonstrators took hold of Lebanon’s capital, fueled by widespread outrage after a blast in Beirut’s port that killed at least 154 people and destroyed entire neighborhoods.

results.title: The Voting Will End Nov. 3. The Legal Battle Probably Won’t.
results.abstract: As the two parties clash over how to conduct an election in a pandemic, President Trump’s litigiousness and unfounded claims of fraud have increased the likelihood of epic postelection court fights.
results.byline: BY PETER BAKER, NICK CORASANITI, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT AND MAGGIE HABERMAN

multimedia.caption: Counting ballots in Florida after the 2000 election. Court fights after the 2020 campaign are shaping up to be more intense.
Counting ballots in Florida after the 2000 election. Court fights after the 2020 campaign are shaping up to be more intense.

results.title: C.D.C. Closes Some Offices Over Bacteria Discovery
results.abstract: The move highlights the risk of Legionnaires’ disease outbreaks when buildings are reopened after coronavirus lockdowns.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: C.D.C. headquarters in Atlanta. The agency had to again close some office space it leases after Legionella bacteria was detected in water supplies.

results.title: Frances Allen, Who Helped Hardware Understand Software, Dies at 88
results.abstract: One of the few women in the computer industry in its early days, she paved the way for the efficient, lightning-fast apps of today.

multimedia.caption: Frances Allen in 2003 at IBM’s  T.J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. She was the first woman to win the A.M. Turing Award, often called the Nobel Prize of computing.

results.title: How to Diversify Orchestras
results.abstract: Readers offer their ideas in response to the music critic Anthony Tommasini’s suggestion that blind auditions be ended.

multimedia.caption: In 1969, when two Black musicians accused the New York Philharmonic of discrimination, the violinist Sanford Allen (center) was the orchestra’s only Black member. Today, just one full-time player is Black: Anthony McGill, the principal clarinet.

results.title: How Kristi Noem, Mt. Rushmore and Trump Fueled Speculation About Pence’s Job
results.abstract: After Ms. Noem, the South Dakota governor, flew to Washington on Air Force One, rumors about her ambitions ensued. She made a second trip to smooth things over with Mike Pence.
results.byline: BY JONATHAN MARTIN AND MAGGIE HABERMAN

multimedia.caption: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota told Vice President Mike Pence that she wanted to help him and President Trump win re-election however she could.

results.abstract: The demonstration was fueled by fury over the corruption and negligence of the country’s ruling elite. Security forces fired tear gas to push back the protesters.

results.title: Trump Threatens to Use Executive Order for ‘Critical Relief’
results.abstract: Though it’s unclear whether he has the authority to do so, President Trump said on Friday that if Congress did not reach an agreement, he would act unilaterally to extend a coronavirus economic aid package.

results.title: Pelosi Is Playing Hardball on Coronavirus Relief. She Thinks She’ll Win.
results.abstract: Emboldened by Republican divisions and a favorable political landscape, the speaker is refusing to agree to a narrow relief measure, unbothered by charges that she is an impediment to a deal.
results.byline: BY EMILY COCHRANE AND NICHOLAS FANDOS
des_facet: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

multimedia.caption: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer have held multiple negotiating sessions in her office with top administration officials. Her strategy carries substantial political risk and real collateral damage, at least in the short term.
